title: Monday, 22nd May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:03am

Monday then. Let's get on with this.

BE11:03am

Those with us on Friday might remember that Murph's off for a bit.

BE11:04am

"Sabbatical".

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Meaning you have me for as long as either of us can stand that circumstance, plus a rotating cast of guest co-presenters.

BE11:05am

Except not today, because it's Monday.

BE11:05am

Picture then!

11:05 am
BE11:05am

BE11:05am

That's the work of https://twitter.com/sirsandgoblin

BE11:05am

Who does election polls in needlepoint.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Why? Dunno. Why not, I guess.

BE11:06am

What it shows (in needlepoint) is the red line edging nearer to the blue line, which is about the only thing that's going on this morning.

BE11:07am

Yep! It's a "sterling down, stocks up" day.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

(@Runner: sorry, that's not my story. I know nothing whatsoever. Yours sincerely, BE.)

BE11:09am

Let my grab the Jim Reid's sum, he being the most readable of the morning strategists.

BE11:10am

Closer to home Brexit has also been an early topic of conversation this morning following comments from Brexit Secretary David Davis over the weekend in the Sunday Times. He said that the UK will quit talks on leaving the EU unless the bloc drops its demand to charge a €100bn divorce payment. Davis said that negotiations would be plunged into “chaos” from the beginning because the EU would be unwilling to negotiate unless Britain agreed to pay. Davis also said that €1bn would be “alot of money” and that “we don’t need to just look like we can walk away, we need to be able to walk away”. Sterling was down about -0.40% at one stage this morning (it’s now about -0.28%) although that might also reflect some of the recent election opinion polls in recent days which have shown the Labour party as cutting the gap to the Tories. An Orb/Telegraph poll over the weekend showed the Tories as holding a 12% lead over Labour at 46% to 34%. The same pollster showed a lead for the Conservatives of 14% back on May 13th. There was a similar result in the YouGov/Times poll where the latest lead of 9% is down from 13% just a week ago. It’s still too early to say that this is a trend but it’s certainly worth keeping an eye on in the near term. Staying with the UK, one thing I forgot to mention last week is that the Conservative manifesto included a pledge to balance the budget by 2025-2026 a few years later than they previously anticipated. It's perhaps further evidence that the balance is slowly shifting from monetary to fiscal policy on a global scale.
It won't be a straight line but if politicians want to avoid Brexit and Trump like populist movements then they are probably going to need to spend more. This will carry on until bond markets rebel and at that point we'll either see a huge crisis or more likely central bank buying more debt again leaving us with helicopter money. I'm not sure I can see any other medium long term scenario really.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

(@Runner: next month. You're on your own until then, I'm afraid. And generally rather than specifically, our stock advice in these circumstances is that if you're worried about your investment then sell it and stop worrying.)

BE11:11am

........ Conveniently, there's a big Barclays sector wrap out this morning advising buy British.

BE11:12am

Which we can credit, at least in part, for things like ....

Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,744, up 30 (+1.75%), High: 1,745, Low: 1,718, Volume: 354.08k
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 391.43, up 6.53 (+1.70%), High: 392.00, Low: 385.20, Volume: 1.95m

(Which gets added to the domestic basket.)

11:12 am
WH Smith PLC (SMWH:LSE): Last: 1,796, up 22 (+1.24%), High: 1,797, Low: 1,778, Volume: 74.66k
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 72.31, up 0.53 (+0.74%), High: 72.43, Low: 71.84, Volume: 38.18m
BE11:13am

So ..........

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Domestic UK remains one of the least favoured areas in the market for the majority of investors we speak with. With valuations near financial crisis lows, investors appear to be pricing in recession. International companies, however, are now responding to the value in the UK, with inbound M&A at record highs. Economic data in the UK has been fairly robust post-Brexit, and our Barclaycard data remains strong. The critics would however suggest that the worst is yet to come.

BE11:14am

(I'm not sure credit card lending data is that comforting a datapoint given the propensity towards denial in those whose jackets are on a shaky nail, bit what do I know.)

BE11:15am

Cross-checking the Consumer: The key to the economy remains in the hands of the consumer, in our view. With the UK inemployment rate now at multi-decade lows,
inflation pressures peaking in Q3 2016 and survey data pointing to wage acceleration, consumer confidence should remain well
upported hereon. Household savings rates, once adjusted for non-cash items, do not look alarming. Both consumer lending and household leverage statistics remain below the levels seen during the previous cycle.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

The FTSE 250 remains cheaply priced relative to the FTSE 100, despite surprisingly seeing significant EPS upgrades post-Brexit. Sectorally, UK General Retail stocks appear to be pricing in a further 20 point drop in consumer confidence. UK Banks, Homebuilders and Travel & Leisure stocks also appear cheaply priced. UK Real Estate stocks appear to be pricing in a 20% decline in book value, at a time when the IPD capital values index has started to tick higher.

BE11:15am

Want some graphs with that?

BE11:16am

11:16 am
BE11:16am

BE11:17am

For more of that, speak to Barclays.

undefined
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Should mention Paysafe, I guess.

Paysafe Group PLC (PAYS:LSE): Last: 471.50, down 11.7 (-2.42%), High: 474.10, Low: 440.50, Volume: 2.60m
BE11:19am

"Spotlight Research" has had not one but two pops this morning.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

https://seekingalp...s#regular_articles

BE11:19am

(Does Spotlight Research have its own website? The name, including at companies house, has already been taken by some healthcare information thing.)

BE11:20am

So, part one goes over the old theme that Paysafe is big in China.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Albeit not as big as Spotlight suggested in its previous report.

BE11:21am

You'll remember Paysafe said post Spotlight's first attack that it might exit China.

BE11:21am

I guess this cranks up the pressure on the company to do that.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Otherwise, though, there isn't a lot new versus the December report.

BE11:22am

Barclays does a point by point breakdown of the first note.

BE11:22am

1. Chinese Bet365 exposure
The new report seemingly acknowledges that the prior Spotlight estimate that the Major Merchant Asia Gateway may represent 50% of Paysafe’s earnings may have been too high, as we argued in our report Irrational fear of the unknown, 3 Feb 2017. In the new report, Spotlight argues that “even taking the low end of sellside estimates for MMAG China exposure, which were generally in the ~15-25% range, the business would still be very material to Paysafe”; we don’t dispute this. The report argues, however, that it is unlikely that the non-China major merchant exposure would have grown as strongly as implied by these numbers. However, it seems not to recognise that the major Skrill acquisition brought considerable inorganic Major Merchant revenue exposure and that, crucially, this is general revenue exposure outside China. It also argues that the associated OpEx may be lower, but Paysafe do not disclose this.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

2. Market is not dealing with other aspects of the prior note
The report argues that following the last note, the market focused on the exposure to the major merchant as opposed to a number of other assertions in that Spotlight made. This is understandable, given the nature of the key accusation. We have not reviewed the other points in detail again, but we would argue that the current focus should be on the present and future shape of the business, as opposed to historic issues which are common across the online processing sector. We did deal with the prior report accusations at the time, as shown in the table below.

BE11:23am

(@chad_john: yep.)

BE11:23am

3. Chinese crackdown on gambling
Another point raised in the report is on China’s efforts to crack down online gambling targeting Chinese citizens. The report discusses Operation Chain Break, China's two-year-old crackdown on cross-border gambling, which the Chinese Ministry of Public Security outlined would enter a new phase. Operation Chain Break also targets 'underground banks and online payment platforms who provide capital settlement to cross-border online gambling'. Comments around this programme are generally true, however, we would like to highlight that Operation Chain Break is a two year old programme so this is not new news.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

That's Geradus Vos, who at the time of writing hadn't got to the Turkey stuff.

BE11:24am

The accusation there being Paysafe is still active in Turkey despite having officially exited in 2014. And that's one I assume the company will respond to in time.

BE11:25am

Geradus also provides a handy summary of his previous response.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

BE11:25am

(I remember once having a long argument with Geradus outside a pub, in 2003 or thereabouts, about Autonomy.)

BE11:25am

(He was a buyer. And was right, in the end, of course. At least in terms of share price direction.)

11:29 am

undefined
BE11:03am

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily this.

11:30 am
Micro Focus International PLC (MCRO:LSE): Last: 2,375, down 97 (-3.92%), High: 2,436, Low: 2,369, Volume: 612.61k
BE11:32am

Credit Suisse asked a bunch of Heads of IT what they were coding these days.

BE11:33am

They all said, "hey, yo, I'm doing the codez in Python, Ruby, PHP, I'm down with the kids."

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Very few said Cobol, unsurprisingly.

BE11:34am

From that, CS seems to have concluded that Cobol's on the way out.

BE11:35am

Which is ... well, I dunno.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Isn't it a bit like a arguing Birale's on the way out because no-one's learning it. It's still quite important to people who only speak Birale.

BE11:36am

Still ... here's the working.

BE11:37am

Digital transformation in the enterprise space is putting structural pressure on legacy technology: In this Ideas Engine, we examine the pressures on legacy technology, focusing on the results of our proprietary survey of over 100 CIOs. Our survey reveals that 65% of respondents think the move away from COBOL has accelerated in the past three years, consistent with an acceleration in momentum behind digital transformation. This is a meaningful datapoint that suggests it is time to re-open the debate around the sustainability of legacy technology.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Downgrade to Underperform: We downgrade Micro Focus to Underperform (from Neutral) and cut our target price to 1,922p (from 2,150p). Micro Focus's management has a strategy of consolidating mature, legacy assets. However, just as investors finally seem to have accepted management's view that legacy assets are sticky, we think the risks to this business model are starting to increase. For Micro Focus, dealing with structural pressures on the business has a cost that is manifested in a permanent restructuring burden. This restructuring means that cash conversion at Micro Focus is just 75% of profits, substantially lower than industry peers at closer to 100%. We think investors should pay more attention to this persistent mismatch between profits and cash flow. Using free cash flow as a driver of valuation to capture this cost could see downside to 1,743p in our Grey Sky scenario.

BE11:37am

Risk/reward is skewed to the downside: We have put together pro forma numbers to consider the P&L and cash flow of the enlarged entity following the planned merger with HPE Software (expected to close on 1 September 2017). We have also broken out divisional estimates to enable investors to value SUSE separately. We use these forecasts as the basis for our sum-of-the-parts valuation. The key risk to our view is investors continuing to overlook the persistent cash costs of restructuring.

BE11:38am

I mean...... there are any number of things to worry about with Micro Focus.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Buying a lump of HP is quite a big one.

BE11:39am

But worrying about Cobol somehow getting coded out of mission-critical IT because some guys in black tee-shirts and stonewash say that's what's happening?

BE11:39am

Nah.

11:39 am
undefined
BE11:40am

(@Dead Cat Bounce: I don't know what BG and WPG are, sorry.)

BE11:40am

To the risers then.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Intertek.

Intertek Group PLC (ITRK:LSE): Last: 4,252, up 85.44 (+2.05%), High: 4,277, Low: 4,206, Volume: 112.77k
BE11:41am

That's ....... uh, I've forgotten. Kepler, was it?

11:41 am
BE11:42am

(@Arash: yep, saw, ta.)

BE11:42am

We upgrade the stock from Hold to Buy and raise our TP from 3935p to 4600p ahead of Q1 results on 26 May. We are bullish on the TIC sector’s cyclical inflection, which Intertek’s management is poised to leverage via acquisitions and gradual productivity improvements from its 5x5 strategic initiatives.

BE11:42am

Yes. Kepler.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

We expect no major changes in the trends reported in Q4 with “good" Products sales (+5% organic) and+3% organic growth in Trade activities. Intertek’s Resources division should remain a major drag this year. The group is guiding for an 8-12% organic sales decline in Resources for the full year, even after a -13% organic decline in 2016. The consolidation of the PSI pipeline inspection business added 5% to the division’s sales last year, while Mining inspection activities represent est. 13% of the division’s total, thereby exposing an est. 82% of the division’s sales to the collapse in oil capex, which is still running at high-double-digit rates (-15-20%), hence our expectations of a -12% organic drop in Q1, which should be the low point of the year.

BE11:43am

The trading statement will probably reiterate the FY guidance set in March, hence our unchanged forecasts. It should be enough to reassure that organic sales growth are on an accelerating trend and that margins should continue to improve, despite Resources. In addition, we believe the 5x5 strategic initiatives are delivering quick results, allowing Intertek to free up cash that CEO André Lacroix has promised to redeploy into earnings-accretive acquisitions. Leveraging the group to 2x EBITDA could buy up to GBP350-400m of sales or13-14% more sales than currently assumed, leaving plenty of upside surprise potential up and above the ongoing cyclical recovery. Our previous TP argued for a P/E of 21x. Our new target P/E of 24x takes into account the ongoing momentum, the 13% compounding effects of forward-looking earnings growth and cash returns as well as the chances of upgrades, be it organic or M&A-driven.

BE11:43am

(@wayneJ: assembly or go home.)

undefined

Okay! As noted on the right, we have an Arsenal statement.

BE11:45am

http://www.investe...1705221022238202F/

11:44 am

Response to media speculation

KSE UK, Inc notes the recent media speculation concerning its shareholding in Arsenal Holdings PLC

and confirms that its shares are not, and never have been, for sale.

KSE is a committed, long term investor in Arsenal and will remain so.

BE11:45am

BE11:46am

BE11:50am

What else, then?

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Some mention of Pets at Home earlier, for not obvious reason.

Pets at Home Group PLC (PETS:LSE): Last: 165.19, up 4.49 (+2.80%), High: 165.60, Low: 161.50, Volume: 566.19k
BE11:50am

A stock we've talked about a lot on here previously.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

There's lots of stuff in the archive, I think, about natural ceilings on its ability to expand vets practice partnerships to non-urban areas where scale-cost advantages aren't too useful.

BE11:52am

But the price has been mullered. I'd suggest this is just a rally into results.

BE11:53am

Morgan Stanley can preview those for us, and not just because it's very negative on the name.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Key Focus:
Unlike the previous year Pets at Home did not issue a trading statement at the end of
FYQ4, so the LFL performance in FYQ4 will be 'n ew news'. FYQ3 was a difficult quarter
in the Food & Accessories side of the business with a LFL of -0.5%. We do not anticipate
much improvement in FYQ4, though believe that continued weak performance in the
quarter is already reflected in consensus forecasts, so do not anticipate that the FY16/17
profits will be materially different from current market expectations.
However, we believe that outer year consensus forecasts are at risk. We anticipate that
management will guide down gross margins (MSe -200bps over the next three years) as
Pets at Home seeks to improve its value perception. Our Pre Tax Profit forecast for FY
2017/18 (£87m) is around 10% below current consensus (£94m).

BE11:54am

Numbers Thursday.

undefined
11:55 am
BE11:55am

(@Dead Cat: Garnier are a bit touchy about such things. I'll try tho.)

BE11:57am

Five minutes left, still not much happening. What can fill the time?

BE11:58am

Clariant! Yes. Thanks WayneJ.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

It's a $20bn deal so we should probably mention it.

BE11:59am

Merger of equals.

BE11:59am

All paper.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Quick thoughts from Bernstein.

BE11:59am

Our initial thoughts are that the merger will 1) be mid-single digit accretive to EPS, 2) require few if any anti-trust divestitures, 3) and is all about cost synergies. We see a less appealing strategic rationale for Clariant as it increases the company's cyclicality, reduces its margin, requires further restructuring (after GANO and Süd-Chemie) and re-enters the company into non-core business areas such as textile chemicals.

BE11:59am

Clariant shareholders will receive 52% of HuntsmanClariant (1 share for each current Clariant share) while Huntsman shareholders will receive 1.2196 shares for each Huntsman share. At the same time, Huntsman will continue to pursue the IPO of its Pigments and Additives business (Venator) by summer. The combined entity will have c.$13.2bn in sales and $1.9bn EBITDA (2016 pro-forma, pre-synergies), i.e. 14.3% EBITDA margin.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

The companies guide for $400mn of cost-synergies, split into $150mn from procurement and $250mn from operational synergies. One-time costs are expected to be up to $500mn. While we see the target at 3%/combined sales as realistic, our initial thoughts are that adjustments for restructuring costs and cash-outs will enter Clariant into a renewed phase of restructuring. Clariant has a rich history of change, and previous programs (e.g. GANO, Süd-Chemie) required a lot of patience from shareholders and limited value creation.

BE12:02pm

............. And Raymond James.

BE12:02pm

This deal will provide Clariant with better access to China, which has been a key focus of growth, as well as a more diversified portfolio of products for both companies. Huntsman has restructured its portfolio recently with the sale of its European surfactants business in 2016, and the proposed IPO spin-off of its Pigments and Additives in the summer of 2017, and we expect the proposed deal to form a company with stronger presence in the specialty chemicals market. We do not expect any material anti-trust issues given the small overlap of their existing portfolios of products.

12:03 pm
undefined
BE12:04pm

Apologies, ROTR. I'm going to have to break into your discussion about Alzheimers care provision funding because we're now at an end of this live financial markets blog.

BE12:05pm

Thanks for joining, folks, and for being incomparably you. Come back tomorrow for more of the same.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

(@Mouselet: Thumbs up)

BE12:05pm

Afternoon all.

BE11:31am

Back to fallers then.
